characters: KNIFE, CREEPING DOWN THE LOW ROOFTOP, DIRECTLY BEHIND HIM
THE LENGTH OF THE BLADE WITH A WHINING SCREECH, SCORING A
GROOVE INTO IT FROM GUARD TO TIP.
MERE FRACTION OF THE REBEL FORCE. LAUGHTER RIPPLES DOWN F
DRACO...AN EERIE, ETHEREAL GLOW OF TRANSLUCENT IRRIDESCEN
CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM MANY MORE GALLOPING HOOVES TO REVE
BENEATH THE SKIN OF HIS AILING SHOULDER. THE DRAGON MOANS
BUT EINON HAS MADE A TACTICAL MISTAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SWORD flashes in the sunlight as it whirls down on... SIR BOWEN...a ruggedly handsome knight who catches the bl on his own, just inches from his face, and smiles through crossed swords, eyes gleaming like the sunlit steel.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Not bad! He disengages his blade with swift flare and, in a dazzli series of sallies, forces his OPPONENT back.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: But not good enough to... The opponent, BACK TO CAMERA, is shoved to the ground, Bowen's sword tip at his throat.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: «+-to live! Bowen grins down at... PRINCE EINON...a fourteen year old boy, his face flush fr exertion. Emblazoned on his surcote is a DRAGON'S HEAD impaled on a sword. A HERALDIC COAT-OF-ARMS. Suddenly, Einon kicks Bowen's blade aside with his boot, rolls, and springs up, lunging at the knight. Again, Bowe deflects the blade by inches. Smiling. Pleased.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Better! Einon is also pleased. He smiles at Bowen's praise and le down his guard. Just slightly. But enough. With a nimble parry, Bowen blade arcs down, striking the startled boy.. only with the flat of the blade on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: But you'd still be dead! Einon reels back and, with a snarl, charges wildly at Bow who, laughing, leaps upon a crumbling piece of stone, eas deflecting or ducking the violent but clumsy blows.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Purpose, not passion, Einon! Fight with your head, not your heart!  He punctuates each maxim with a slap of his sword flat, obviously toying with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Nerve cold-blue, blade blood-red. Einon slices wickedly at Bowen's legs. Bowen leaps up as blade swishes harmlessly under him. But as he lands, the edge of the stone crumbles beneath the heel of his boot. teeters, then tumbles off the rock, out of sight behind i Einon's savage fighting demeanour slides into a shocked g of concern.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Sir Bowen? He scrambles over the stone to find Bowen sprawled out on ground, apparently unconscious. As Einon leans down to examine him, he's suddenly distracted by HOOFBEATS. He whirls to the sound as... RIDERS...gallop toward them. As Einon squints in the sun identify them, A FIGURE towers up behind him and a sword glints at his throat. Bowen leers over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Dead again, Prince! How many times must I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (reciting together) Only expose your back to a corpse! But the fencing lesson is over. Einon points to the rider

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: It's happened. Bowen scowls as Three Riders approach, led by A MASSIVE B OF A KNIGHT...SIR BROK...Einon knows why he's come.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: The peasants are revolting.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: (grins) They've always been revolting, Prince. Smell one sometime. But now they're rebelling. (to Bowen) King Freyne would have his son witness his noble victory.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (contemptuous1ly) Noble...? Crushing desperate, frightened men...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Traitorous scum! The King commands. Bring him. You can watch too, nursemaid. He whips his horse and rides off with the others. Bowen turns to get his and Einon's horses. . Einon is disappoin that Bowen allowed Brok's insult to go unchallenged.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Why do you let him insult you like that? You, a Knight of the Old Code! You're not afraid of him!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Nor his opinions. I expect no less. (distaste) He's the king's man. Einon registers Bowen's contempt for the king with an une scowl, but as Bowen turns to hand him his reins, the boy beams affectionately at him.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: When I am king, you will be my man, Bowen. Bowen claps him warmly on the shoulder and helps the prin into the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I am already your man, my prince. He swings into the saddle and, as the two ride after Brok CAMERA PANS TO THE GALLOPING HOOVES.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM MANY MORE GALLOPING HOOVES TO REVE
dialogues.text: A TROOP OF MOUNTED, ARMOURED KNIGHTS...as they ride out o the smoke and dust of battle. At their head is... KING FREYNE...sword aloft. Visor raised. Eyes hard and hateful. On his helmet glints a GOLD CIRCLET. A CROWN. Emblazoned on his surcote is the same DRAGON’S HEAD impal on a sword we saw on Einon's surcote. He rides through the carnage of a 10th CENTURY BATTLE, leading mounted SOLDIERS against a RABBLE OF PEASANTS. Slashing with mad glee, Freyne mows down men armed only w crude farm implements. It is slaughter as the rebels are driven back through their own crude lines of defense...ov turned carts, ditches, an earthen bulwark. None of which impede Freyne's onslaught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen and Einon sit their horses on a hillock behind the lines watching the carnage. Bowen is disgusted, Einon fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: I wish we were down there.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (curtly) You don't.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Ido. Just to see you in action, Bowen. Yours would be the finest blade on the field.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Too fine to foul with your father's slaughter. In a quiet, hurt tone, Einon gently reminds Bowen of good manners and protocol.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: He is my father, Bowen. And the king. Bowen takes the admonishment with a kind smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Yes...But when you are king, remember today. Remember the difference between battle and butchery. And remember the Qld Code. Restore its forgotten glory, so that the crown will shine with honour once more and never again will men have to take up arms against their sovereign. Then you will be a greater king than your father. Bowen turns to watch the ungallant battle with weary eyes thus doesn't see the dark glint in Einon's gaze,

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: I promise, Bowen, I will be greater. And no one will take arms against me...Look! Father's breached the village. He points to the king down below, galloping toward the bulwark, cutting down men right and left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freyne descends on a YOUTH -- wearing a BUCKET with one s cut out as a crude helmet -~ who stumbles between two HAYRACKS mounted in a gap in the bulwark. A large meaty paw reaches out and grabs BUCKETHEAD by th jerkin, yanking the youth behind... THE BULWARK...Buckethead flops into a LARGE MUD PUDDLE on other side. Buckethead's saviour is a RED-BEARDED GIANT, whose unruly mane is bound by a LEATHER HEAD-BAND. Armed with a scythe, Red-beard knocks the sword from Frey hand as the king rides in through the breach. Another reb charges the king with a burning torch, but gets a gauntle the face as Freyne punches him and snatches his torch. He whirls his steed back for the bulwark. But Red-beard signals several men at the hayracks, who pu SPIKED WOODEN BREASTWORKS out from under the racks and cu off Freyne's escape route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen and Einon watch from their vantage point as a HORDE VILLAGERS chase the trapped Freyne. Freyne zig-zags his horse in and out and under the stilts of SEVERAL RAISED GRAINHOUSES, torching some as he passes. But the peasants are closing in.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: (anxiously) He's trapped! The boy draws his sword and spurs his horse down the hill through the melee!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Einon, no! He follows after the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen closes in on his young charge when he's beset by RE WARRIORS. He ducks the savage thrust of a pitchfork and, grabbing the shaft, cracks the WIELDER under the jaw with blunt end. Another rebel gets clouted by Bowen's boot eve as the knight knocks another down with the shaft of the pitchfork. He kills no one. But even as he scatters them, he's lost Einon in the dusty haze of the battle. He shout

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Einon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red-beard and a MOTLEY BAND OF REBELS close in on Freyne, king's horse snorts and rears as Freyne whirls his torch, trying to pry an opening through the rebel mass. But they catch him under one of the granaries and pull h from the saddle. Freyne clanks to the ground in a cacopho of armour and chainmail. at the feet of... BUCKETHEAD...who's shoved aside again as Redbeard and the others crowd around the fallen king. Crude weapons rise a fall. Buckethead jerks away, unable to watch. Then it's over as RED-BEARD and the others race to defend their village from Freyne's men who have breach the barricade. Only Buckethead remains, queasily staring at t dead king. A WILD WAIL pierces the battle clamour.

dialogues.speaker: EINON, (0S)
dialogues.text: Father! -Buckethead swiftly clambers up the granary ladder as... EINON...gallops through a veil of smoke over the bulwark. Dismounting, he scrambles to his father, laying a hand to lifeless breast... and pulling it back with a shudder, covered in blood. Stunned, Einon stares from his hand to his father and then...to the crown...perched atop Freyne's helmet. Trembling, he reaches over the body for it. As he does, Freyne's eyes suddenly FLICKER OPEN AND STARE into Einon' who hesitates...then snatches the crown off anyway...even Freyne groans his last and his eyes glaze in deathly admonishment at his heir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Einon pulls back from his dead father, he holds up the crown. It glints brilliantly in the firelight. Something else also glints. Buckethead's KNIFE as Einon sees the flying body leap off the granary platform down onto him. The impact of their collision sends the boys sprawling ac the ground spilling against a breastwork, a jumble of arm and legs. The bucket helmet clatters off as the rebel flo face-down, a cascade of red hair falling toe his shoulder Einon lurches off the breastwork, grasping a STAKE for support. It is sticky with BLOOD. His blood. It oozes fro a gash in his chest, spilling across his ripped dragonhea crest. Einon spies the CROWN half-in, half-out of a mud puddle. weaves toward it on unsteady legs, then sags into the mud his fingers locking on the circlet. Gasping weakly, he st glassy-eyed at Buckethead, staggering up. Even unhelmeted, Buckethead's face is A BLUR in Einon's h vision. All he sees is flaming hair, blending into the fi light of a hut burning behind then.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN, (0S)
dialogues.text: Einon! Einon's vision pops into crystal clear FOCUS as Buckethe whirls to the anguished CRY...and we discover THE BOY IS GIRL!. Her name is...as we later learn...KARA. She's roughly Einon's age and even the grime of battle cannot h her beauty, haloed in an aureole of gleaming red hair. As Kara sees Bowen's steed leap over the breastworks and Bowen wildly spins the horse toward the fallen Einon, lea down in the saddle and scooping up his wounded charge.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Bowen!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I'm here, my prince...my king. He whirls his horse back around and, sideswiping, a BARRE OF MILK, bounds over the barricade once more. Kara dives of the way, landing near the spilt milk now running into mixing with the blood of battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Einon slumps back in Bowen's arms as the horse charges through the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A WOODEN FORTRESS looms out of the shadow of a mountain. Grimly impressive. Bowen's steed breaks from the forest a races across the plain toward the Fortress gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wounded Brok kneels before AISLINN, the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: Dead, Madam...King Freyne, your husband, slain. She takes the news stoically, staring out the window in impassive resignation. A DOOR slams open. Aislinn spins t the sound. Silhouetted in the light of the open door stan a KNIGHT, A LIMP FORM CRADLED IN HIS ARMS. With a gut-sinking premonition, Aislinn weaves to the doo A single TEAR trickles muddily down Bowen's grimey face a Aislinn gasps at her crumpled son.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, my Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault. The cruel excesses of his father brought him to this end. She gestures to a bed. Bowen lays him on it.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: The crown...

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN
dialogues.text: He lives!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: He dies, Madan... Bowen slides the crown off his arm and places it in the b vhand.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: «+.Beyond all help.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Not all... Aislinn turns to Bowen...curiously calm even hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun sinks behind a promontory as FIGURES trek through RUINS OF AN OLD CASTLE up the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aislinn, on horseback, leads Bowen and a body of GUARDS u mountain path, through the RUINS OF AN ANCIENT ROMAN CAST Brok and the others bear Einon on a hide stretcher suppor on spears. Walking his horse, Bowen hovers over the semi- conscious boy who still grips the crown and talks to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (reciting) A knight is sworn to valour...

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: +«.sworn... to valour...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: His heart knows only virtue...

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: .--virtue...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: His blade defends the helpless. His might upholds the weak... Bowen is suddenly distracted by an EERIE MUSICAL TRILLIN Sad and melancholy. It comes from further up the mountain The others hear it as well. Except for Einon whose mumble drifts to a groan. Bowen shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: You must stay awake, my lord. You must! Recite the code...

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: -.-code...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Yes! His might upholds the weak...

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: -.-his...word speaks only truth...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Yes... yes... His wrath...?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (reciting together) His wrath undoes the wicked.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Night has descended. The moon glows a bright scarlet. The party stops before a CAVE, lighting torches. Bowen dismou and gathers Einon off the stretcher into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aislinn takes a torch and starts into the cave. From with echoes the mournful, musical TRILL. Bowen eyes her warily

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I know what place this is. It has the stink of dragon.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Not the Dragon's stench; merely man's pollution of him. Come and fear not! Aislinn enters. Bowen, Einon in his arms, hesitantly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even torchlight cannot dispel the gloom. Their light and shafts of scarlet moonlight, seeping through two holes in cavern roof, illuminate bubbling mud pits and bones. Stea wreathes through the place. From the cave's recesses come faint IRRIDESCENT RIPPLE OF MOVEMENT. And the melancholy TRILL. Toward this Aislinn cautiously, humbly, approaches  10

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Lord! Serene One! Her voice echoes. The TRILLING stops. The Guards murmur uneasily. Bowen warily eyes The GLOW. It seems BRIGHTER. Defining an UNCERTAIN SHAPE. Aislinn signals for silence.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Your song is sad tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: There are no stars in the sky? The VOICE...sad yet strangely soothing... comes from the large, eerie shape shimmering in the shadows. It, too, is large and eerie. Aislinn moves to the glow.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: No...only a moon. Blood-red. Bowen eases Einon down. Hovering protectively over him, suspiciously listening, his eye never leaving the creatur the shadows. The peculiar irridescence is the beast's sca hide that emits a wavering glow as he shifts.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Aislinn. Daughter of Athelstun.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Yes, Lord, whose people loved you and called your kind friend.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Once. Long ago. No more. No longer fickle man's friend. Feared. Forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: I have not forgotten. I do not fear. Einon sighs. Aislinn kneels beside Bowen to comfort her s stroking his brow, as the boy feverishly fondles the crow The Dragon's half~hooded eye glints from the darkness, surveying the prince. The crown caressed in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Freyne's child. Aislinn desperately whirls on the dragon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Is this why you come, Draonslayer's wife?  il

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Dragonslayer's widow! A bride of conquest! My people driven out and slaughtered even as yours. (kneels) Please! He's not his father. (points to Bowen) This knight is his mentor. He has taught him the Old Code. And I will teach him your ways. The dragon's scales brightly ripple. He considers her ple his baleful eye falling on the boy's bloody breast.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: The wound is deep. You know what you ask?

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: (kneels before him) I swear. He will grow in your grace. Grow just and good. The dragon's shadowy head inclines toward Einon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: He must swear. Your sword, knight. Aislinn nods to Bowen. He reluctantly unsheathes it to ha to her, but the Dragon's CLAW emerges from the dark and g the blade in his talons. Bowen instinctively lets go. The dragon extends the hilt to Einon who stirs and, seein the shadowy creature above, gasps.

dialogues.speaker: AISLINN
dialogues.text: Fear not, child, he will save you.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: But first, boy, by the cross of the sword, swear that your Father's bloodlust and tyranny die with him. Swear that you will live and rule with mercy. And come to me and learn. The Once-ways. Swear! "Swear, swear, swear..." his sibilance echoes through the darkness. Einon clutches the sword to his breast.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: I...swear... Einon leans up to kiss the pommel, then suddenly slumps i Bowen's arms. Bowen shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Einon? Einon! He's dead!  12 In angry grief, Bowen grabs the sword hilt to wrest it fr the Dragon. But as he yanks, the Dragon's TALONS SCRAPE D

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Peace, Knight of the Old Code... The Dragon suddenly blows out the torches, immersing them darkness. Save for the occasional glint of his shimmering scales and his glowing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: -».And witness the wonders of an even more ancient glory. The Dragon releases the sword and places a talon against breast, IMPALING it in the scales of his hide. As he slic down his chest, a RED GLOW issues from the wound. Not blo but LIGHT. The dragon reaches into the cut. Sighs. Groans And captures a PULSATING SCARLET BRILLIANCE in his claw, the wound closes over. He holds the glowing orb over the boy. Einon's eyelids flutter open. He smiles, as the beast gently reaches down and the glowing redness seeps into Einon's wound.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Half my heart to make you whole. It's strength to purify your weakness. Live and remember your oath. He pulls his claw back and a THIN SLIVER OF FIRE shoots f the Dragon's nostril along the wound, cauterizing it. But Einon feels no pain. He smiles and his eyelids grow heavy and flutter down. Einon sleeps peacefully. Aislinn gasps joyous sob and hugs the sleeping boy. Bowen is dumbfounde Once more FLAME sprays from the Dragon, relighting the terches, Aislinn rises and bows to the Dragon. She turns, Bowen lifts Einon up in his arms, and, with their entoura they turn to leave. Bowen hesitates and turns to the drag

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I've served the father only for the sake of the son. In him go all the hopes of my heart. Forgive a doubting fool. Call when you've need of me, ask what you will of me. My sword and service are yours. The dragon has faded into the darkness. Only an occasiona shiny scale flickers.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Only remind him always of his vow, Knight of the Old Code.  13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen, on horseback, leads Aislinn's steed down the mount through the Roman ruins once more. Behind them comes Brok and the guard with... EINON. ..asleep on his stretcher, unconsciously fondling crown in his hands. The crown slips from his fingers, clanking to the ground. Einon jerks awake, sitting up bolt straight. A strange, fierce light in his eyes. He's tense with coiled energy. Brok signals the guard to halt and kneels beside Einon.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: Your Majesty? Is all well? Einon unconsciously feels the scar on his chest. Einon ga at it, remembering. The Dragon. He smiles at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: All is very well. The crown. Brok picks it up and offers it to Einon. Eyes afire, Eino takes the crown and firmly plants it on his head. He like the fit.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: Anything more, Your Majesty? Einon turns from his regal reverie to smile grimly at Bro

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Much more. He rises off the stretcher. Brok goes to support him, but Einon pushes him away. He's a little rocky on his feet, b he stands, staring out on the Roman ruins.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: The Romans built a great castle here. Mine will be greater.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: It will take many men, milord, to rebuilt this ruin.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SOLDIERS OF THE KING swarm through the burnt ruin of village. WAILING WOMEN and even SOME CHILDREN have been p to work filling in the barricade ditch, THE VILLAGE MENFO are being rounded up from hiding places and shackled in WOODEN NECK STOCKS.  14 BROK, in charge of this foray, steers his horse through t trampled shambles of a hut and scrapes away debris with h sword, ferreting out a TRAPDOOR beneath the charred clutt He motions to TWO SOLDIERS who jerk open the door, exposi dishevelled REDBEARD hiding below in a root cellar full o cheese. Brok's sword jabs downward. Into a ROUND OF CHEESE. As Br takes a bite of the cheese, Redbeard is yanked out and he toward the other prisoners. Kara, working at the ditch, drops her spade and rushes to him.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Father! Tears in her eyes, she clings to him, but Brok yanks her ‘roughly by the hair and shoves her away. She falls to th ground, rising up to see REDBEARD yoked into a stock with other prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firelight flickers over Einon's face. He sits his horse, next to a SMITHY'S FIRE, savouring the SOUNDS OF CLINKING CHAINS AND SPLINTERED STONE, as he gazes out over... A STONE QUARRY...FETTERED PEASANTS break rocks under the watchful eyes of ARMED GUARDS. Einon watches in malevolen satisfaction as Brok rides in with a half dozen more QUAR SLAVES harnessed together with a length of rope about the neck. Among them is REDBEARD.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Hold, Brok! Brok stops his charges with a rough jerk on the rope. Ein appraisies Redbeard suspiciously. Even in defeat, the big man stares up at the new king with cold contempt. Einon cannot match his stern gaze. Redbeard smiles.

dialogues.speaker: REDBEARD
dialogues.text: Come to thank me, boy? You should. It was my stroke that made you king. Brok yanks Redbeard's head back by his headband, exposing neck to his blade.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: My stoke will make you a corpse!

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: No! The command halts the throat-slitting. Einon glares at Redbeard glaring at him.  15

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: I want no martyrs. And death is a release, not punishment. Einon smiles evilly at Redbeard whose glare hardens but a flickers with faint worry.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: It's an insolent gaze. Look good, dog. And remember. I am your king. The one who crushed you. And the last thing you will ever see. Einon grabs an iron from the smithy's fire. Its tip is white-hot. He flings it to Brok.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Burn that insolence out of his eyes! Grinning, Brok picks up the iron. Redbeard, pale but prou gazes up into the rocks. He shakes his head from side-to- side, almost imperceptibly. To anyone observing, it would merely seem dazed defiance or maybe trembling fear, but i is, in actuality a signal. A signal to... KARA...hidden up behind a boulder. Redbeard is warning th girl to stay put. Stay safe. Weeping, Kara obeys as... BROK...approaches Readbeard, head still high. Eyes still the rocks above. But as Brok raises the iron a SWORD BLAD swoops down and strikes it from his hand. It is... BOWEN'S SWORD...as he gallops past Brok to the prisoners, blade slicing the ropes binding them together.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Run! No encouragement needed, the prisoners scatter for the forest. Bowen's whirlwind appearance confuses Einon's men But one snaps out of it and tries to stop an escapee. Bow comes between them and cuts the soldier down. Meanwhile.. KARA...scrambles out of the rocks and, in the confusion, rushes down to Redbeard.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Father!

dialogues.speaker: REDBEARD
dialogues.text: Kara! Quickly! Einon spots the girl and charges after them, but once mor Bowen rides between the pursuer and the pursued, who duck into the woods. Enraged, Einon bears down on Bowen with d sword. Bowen reluctantly but skillfully defends himself against the attack.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: How dare you defy me!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Einon! You're unwell! Bewitched! (pleading) Don't do this! Remember the code!

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: The king is above the code! Dismayed by this declaration, Bowen drops his guard and E unseats him with a stab in the shoulder. The knight toppl from his mount, falling between the skittish horses. Eino rides over him, whirling triumphantly to acknowledge the cheers of his men. His mistake...for... A MUDDY HAND...reaches up and yanks Einon's leg from the stirrup, shoving it out and up, heaving.... EINON...off his horse. The boy reels over the right flank his horse, flopping to the ground to find... BOWEN...grimly grinning at him through the legs of the ho

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Only expose your back to a corpse. You forget everything I've taught you! Bowen, braced on his blade, bleeding from his shoulder an his head, tries to stagger up. Einon angrily leaps up and, whipping his horse away, lung at Bowen, still on his knees. But even kneeling, Bowen deflects Einon's wild charge.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Control, little warrior! His blade knocks Einon's aside, then rips across the drag crest on the surcote. Bowen, still on his knees, counters Einon's fierce but undisciplined, crazed sallies, critiqu the boy's technique as he does.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Purpose, not passion, Einon. Fight with your head... He slashes Einon's belt. It slides down his legs and trip him up. He lugges savagely atop the tottering Einon, forc him down, poistng his sword tip on the boy's heart.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: ».-not your heart.  17 The heart. His eyes smoldering with pained hurt, Bowen spies the torn dragon on the surcote, which rises and fal along with his blade, in chaotic rhythm to Einon's racing heart. The dragon's heart. The dragon. It's almost as though he can hear the cursed heart beating. Thump. Thump Thump. Pulsing with treacherous life. With a mad, griefstricken wail, Bowen raises his sword... jabs it in the ground beside Einon's head, staring at the with sorrow-filled eyes. His voice rasps with choked emotion.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: No one is above the code. Least of all, a king! ‘He leans down and kisses the boy. Tears well in his eyes he whirls up and sharply whistles. As Bowen's steed gallo up, Einon scrambles away, grasping his cheek where Bowen kissed him. His confused fear quickly turns to anger once more as Bowen mounts and spurs his steed off into the for

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Seize him! Bring him down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen gallops off through the sun-streaked trees. THE CAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KARA & REDBEARD..-.hiding in a tree, as Einon and his min ride in pursuit of Bowen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen emerges from the dragon cave. In frustrated fury, h clangs his drawn sword against the rock. His horse whinni nervously, as the shrieking clang echoes out over the mountains where a shimmering half-orb of SUNLIGHT splays across a purple-orange sky.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: No matter where you fly, Dragon, no matter where you hide, I will find you! My oath will not save you! All bonds are broke by your betrayal. I make a new vow! I will undo your treachery!...Even if I must spend the rest of my life hunting you and your kind down! In the distance, Bowen's echoing oath is answered by A MOURNFUL TRILL...Every mountain seems to reverberate with tortured KEENING as the CAMERA PULLS BACK, capturing Bowe the golden flood of the sinking sun. WE HEAR A VOICE.  18

dialogues.speaker: FRIAR GILBERT, (VO)
dialogues.text: This is the tale of a Knight who slew a Dragon and vanquished Evil. GOLDEN LIGHT overwhelms the screen as a SUPERIMPOSED LEGE

dialogues.speaker: "TWELVE YEARS LATER"
dialogues.text: The GOLDEN LIGHT becomes... WHEAT...waving gently in the morning breeze. Behind the w of grain comes a VOICE...the same we just heard...recitin

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (reciting) "A solitary pilgrim rode Upon his lowly mule,..." CAMERA PANS over the rolling hill of wheat, finding... FRIAR GILBERT...a monk...riding a MULE on a path between wheatfields. Both mule and monk are laden with scrolls and manuscripts Bundles of parchment protrude from the saddlebags. Slung about the monk's middle is a clothsack filled with scroll As Gilbert recites, he scratches a quill across a scroll unrolled against the mule's neck.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (writing) "Content with this his humble mode, His quest was spiritual..." Except it comes out"spirichool" as he tries to rhyme it w mule. The mule itself begins to buck.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Whoa, Merlin! Whooaa! But Merlin doesn't "whoa" and bucks Gilbert off, who tumb cassock over crucifix, the scrolls from his pouch spillin out on the ground with him.. He sits up with as much dign as he can muster and glares at the mule.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Everyone's a critic. But the mule's only response is to bray nervously and sto impatiently at the ground. Ignoring the tempermental anim Gilbert crawls about gathering up his scrolls, grumbling himself.  19

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Keep faith, Gilbert, keep faith! True, thus far, this quest has been uneventful -.-if not altogether fruitless and boring +..But remember its goals, its glory! Soon, something's bound to happen. Something does. A SUDDEN WHOOSH OF WIND violently rustles wheat and tears at the monk's cassock. The just~gathered scrolls go flying from his grip once more and Gilbert goe flat on his back once more. His eyes widening with fear a they gaze upward, following the path of the wind.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: D-D-Dragon! ‘The GUST OF WIND subsides and the RUSTLING OF WINGS whip away over a hill of wheat which wavers violently in its w Scrambling up, Gilbert scoops up precious scrolls as he t off for the opposite wheatfield. But he screeches to a panicked halt as SOMETHING ELSE charges out of the wheat. Wailing, the frenzied friar flings himself to the ground more in a welter of flying manuscripts.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (crosses himself) Jesu! Gilbert peeks up to see... A KNIGHT...reining in his horse, frowning down at him. It BOWEN. But Bowen is mightily changed since last we saw him. Time has passed and not been kind. His hair is now laced with grey. His face is unshaven. His surcote frayed and torn. His armour dented and dull. He and his steed are laden with assorted weaponry. Broad sword, lance, bow and arrows, mace, battle axe, and buckl This SHIELD gives grim evidence of his trade...and that h has been successful in his vow...an awesome assortment of DRAGON HORNS protrudes from it. Bowen snaps at the friar in curt irritation.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Dra...dra...drag...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Yes! Where? Gilbert gestures with a bent scroll clutched in his shaki hand. Bowen gives chase, he and his mount disappearing ov the hill of wheat.  20 A painful HOWL jerks the priest up, shivering. A BURST OF FIRE erupts in the sky from over the hill. The stalks qui in manic agitation. SOMETHING'S coming toward him! It's Bowen's riderless horse. Gilbert kneels in prayer. He's interrupted by ANOTHER HORRIBLE YOWL! Then... STILLNESS! Gilbert creeps to the wheat, listening. Nothin Then RUSTLING. Close by! A DRAGON HORN pokes through the stalks. Gilbert falls back with a yelp. It's only... BOWEN...holding a SEVERED DRAGON HORN. Bowen goes to his horse and begins to affix his latest tr to his shield. Gilbert scrambles to his feet and, pluckin up scattered scrolls along the way, rushes to the knight.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (arms full of manuscripts) Magnificent! Marvelous! Heroics befitting the days of Arthur and the Round Table, Never have I seen such skill!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Then you must've led the life of a... monk.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: A...Yes...Also scholar, scribe, historian, and poet. Your servant, Brother Gilbert of Glockenspur. My humble life is in the debt of your exalted prowess, dauntless courage, and superb, swift sword.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: You have a poet's gift of exaggeration. Gilbert thinks it's a compliment and holds up a scroll.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, sir! You should read my histories. But you belittle your talent. A great victory for you and the Lord. Bowen wearily examines the mottled, scarred horn.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Then may the Lord savour it. There's too little glory to be shared in this kill.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Modesty as well as valour. The code of ancient Camelot still lives.  21 Bowen jerks his head up with a hostile glare at the menti of the code. Then the glare glazes into wistful sadness. shakes the melancholy from him with a sardonic grin.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Hardly worthy of Camelot...Still it's one less dragon... Bowen looks at the new horn and all the others on his shi with bitter satisfaction. His grim rumination is interrup by CLATTERING HOOVES. An effete, oily lord, FELTON, rides with THREE BURLY MEN-AT-ARMS. Felton deigns to salute Bow with a bejewelled hand.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Well done, Knight. Our gratitude. Mine and King Einon's. Felton yawns blasely. That's it. Interview's over. He turns his horse to go, but Bowen catches the reins.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Keep the gratitude. I'll take gold. Yours or the King's.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Gold, knight? Felton cocks an imperious eyebrow and smiles. Unpleasantl Bowen gets the picture. He's getting the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: We struck a bargain. One dragon put down, one pouch of gold. Gilbert's idea of chivalry is dismayed by this mercenary display.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Your honour has a price, knight?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: It has expenses! Honour cannot fill my belly or shoe my horse. (wheels to Felton) I ask no more than any man. A fair price for a fair skill.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: The priest is right. It is your duty to protect King Einon's vassals as a knight of the realm!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Not of this realm! I bend no knee to Einon.  22

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: No? Then begone, vagabond, before I arrest you for...for... (an inspiration) Poaching the king's wildlife! Felton jerks a finger at the dead dragon. Bowen almost laughs at the ludicrousness of it and he fingers his swor hilt, debating whether to cut this popinjay down to size. But the thugs-at-arms give Felton's threats weight. Bowen grimly smiles and, with a curt bow, mounts up. Suddenly, the timid faces of PEASANTS begin to poke out o the wheat. Felton turns his disdain on them.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Back to work you, lazy scum. If King Einon's wheat isn't cut before the rain, I'll do some cutting of my own. Felton's bully-boys whip the peasants back to the fields. Gilbert, who's watched all in befuddled confusion, grabs mule's reins and timidly approaches Bowen.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Sir knight, for questioning your motives. Times are topsy-turvy and the world is not as it once was.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I've noticed.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Let me make amends. I've a fair culinary flair. Please join me in my evening repast.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Come evening, I shall be far from here, priest. Gilbert mounts and the two head up the ridge.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: So shall I. For I am on a pilgrimage. Might we travel together?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Unless Einon's taxed it, the road's still free and a man may travel which way he chooses, Bowen addresses this last to Felton as he passes by, who ponders as he watches them go...  23

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Einon's prediction was right. His castle is greater than Roman one. And it's not yet completed. But even behind a WARREN OF SCAFFOLDING, it rises out of the spine of the mountain impressive and forbidding. FELTON AND HIS RETINU come riding up the road in through the castle gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courtyard is abuzz with WORKMAN and SERVANTS. GROOMS ATTEND to SADDLE HORSES. FALCONRY MASTERS stand with HOOD BIRDS OF PREY perched on their gloves. There is RAUCOUS LAUGHTER as A GROUP OF MEN move out of the shadow of a portico, led by... EINON...now in his twenties. Tall and tough. Eyes sharp. Mouth cruel. Armed with sword, dagger, and quiver. He's cultivated a wispy beard. He's followed by a COTERIE of KNIGHTS, all dressed for the hunt, among them Brok and Fe who buzzes in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON, (OS)
dialogues.text: A road tax, King Einon. Felton, weighted down with hunting equipment, trips on hi bow. Brok smirks at him. Felton cocks an imperious eyebro at Brok and turns to Einon who weighs Felton's suggestion he mounts a strong steed laden with armour and weapons li himself. Felton fans the flame of his idea.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: They use it. Let them pay for the privilege. Again, he gets caught up in his bow. He untangles himself and indignantly flings it to a nearby servant, finishing thought.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: And those that can't, can work it off! All wait for Einon's response. It comes in a sly smile. H leans over and pats Felton's balding head.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Ingenious, Lord Felton. He plays with a wispy strand of thinning hair.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: There may not be much on top, but there's plenty underneath. He playfully thumps a finger on Felton's skull. Felton ma a sweeping bow.  24 As Felton comes up, Brok reaches in front of him and take his FALCON from an attendent, sweeping it close to Felton face. The bird screeches and flaps its wings, Felton crin back. Brok smirks.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: He likes to bring down peacocks. Shrinking back from Brok, Felton clambers on his horse, b is so weighted down with his hunting paraphenalia, he has tough time swinging into the saddle. Brok grabs him by the seat of the pants and roughly shove him up.

dialogues.speaker: BROK
dialogues.text: Fly, peacock, fly. The others laugh as Felton clumsily grabs the horse's nec keep his balance. Once more, he comes face to face with Brok's hawk that screeches again, eliciting more laughter from Brok and the others...all but Einon.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: Lord Brok. Some are good at hunting men. Some are good at hunting money. Both have value to me. Felton's turn to smirk. But his triumph's shortlived as Einon snatches Felton's bow from the attendent and tosses to the haughty fop.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: So don't forget your bow, Felton, you may need to shoot a ferocious coin purse. Einon joins the others in their laughter this time. And s does a reluctant Felton who gives forth with a forced gid giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the hunt! He spurs his horse out the gate, followed by his minions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many are still working off debts to the young tyrant. Tho the quarry is all but gutted, half-starved ragged PEASANT toil in the sun under the watchful eyes of GUARDS. Many of the QUARRY SLAVES clamor for water, doled out by. KARA...Now grown into a beautiful woman. But both her bea and her lush, wild mane of red hair are hidden underneath ragged cloak. But her proud, youthful face cannot hide ey that are much older, weary with grim experience.  25 Dispensing drinks, she makes her way up behind AN OLD MAN chipping at stone with a chisel and hammer. She scoops a ladle of water out and proffers it to him. We recognize t HEADBAND the old man wears.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Drink, Father. The old man turns. It is REDBEARD! No longer a virile, haughty rebel. Einon recaptured him and carried out his threat. Redbeard is BLIND. Scar tissue surrounds the sightless eyes staring at nothing. But even though his red hair and beard are streaked with white, even though his once-strong body is frail and stoo he still manages an air of his old defiance.

dialogues.speaker: REDBEARD
dialogues.text: I told you not to come here anymore, Kara!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I am a disobediant child, Father. Drink.

dialogues.speaker: REDBEARD
dialogues.text: No longer a child. A woman. And it takes no blind man to tell a beautiful one. His gnarled hand gropes for her face. She leads him to he cheek. He caresses it.

dialogues.speaker: RED-BEARD
dialogues.text: One day on of these dogs will notice too. Go home, Kara.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: You are my home, Father. She kisses his palm. Then takes some COOKED MEAT from her jerkin and stuff it inside his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Here is meat for later. Now quickly, drink. The guard is watching. She places the LADLE in his hand and he starts to lift it his lips. Suddenly AN ARROW ZINGS INTO FRAME, striking th ladle and knocking in from his hand. Kara wheels to LAUGHTER. IT IS... EINON...and his hunting party, laden down with game... pheasant, boars, even a stag. Einon has shot the arrow.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: I don't believe...I mean, magnificent shot, Your Higness.  26

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: And profitable. Unless you care to double the wager, Felton?

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: {takes the bet) Through his legs! Einon notches another arrow and lets fly at... RED-BEARD...already panicked by the first arrow. He hears the whizz of the second as it zips through his legs and clinks on the rock behind him. He whirls frantically.

dialogues.speaker: RED-BEARD
dialogues.text: Kara!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Stand still, father! Felton shouts out another target.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: The bucket-handle! Another arrow slices the air, striking the water bucket handle next to Red-beard and sending it clattering agains the bucket, causing the old man to jump.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Kara!

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Don't move! Kara steps in front of him and heads for... EINON...indignant someone should interfere with his sport He notches another arrow and shoots it in front of Kara's feet. She keeps coming. Another arrow. Only inches frm her. She keeps coming. He aims directly at her. Not a flinch. She keeps coming. Einon lowers his bow, intrigued EINON . You've got nerve for a spoilsport.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: There's no sport in tormenting a sick old man. I beg Your Majesty. Let him go. It's been fourteen years. Your castle is budlt. He can do you no harm. For pity's sake, release him. Einon stares at her curiously. Then smiles. Einon Release him?  27 In one flashy blur of motion, he's notched another arrow sends it flying. Straight into Red-beard's heart. The old Man gasps and staggers back against the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Father! She runs to him, her hood flying back, unleasing her wild tumble of hair. It catches Einon's attention.

dialogues.speaker: EINON
dialogues.text: I've always said death was a release. He spurs his horse and he and his flunkeys ride off as... Kara...kneels beside her father.

dialogues.speaker: RED-BEARD
dialogues.text: K-K-Kara... He goes limp and his head sags. His headband falls off an his hair spills down over his blind eyes. Kara takes the band and, in stunned grief, presses it to her face, sobbi into it.

dialogues.speaker: ON EINON
dialogues.text: Turning on Kara's heartbroken wail. Her rich red hair is captured in the burning light of the Smithy's fire behind her. . The image strikes a memory with Einon, but he can' bring it forth and shrugs it off with an uneasy shiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen and Gilbert sit at a campfire, gnawing on roasted mutton joints. As Bowen affixes his latest trophy to his dragon-horn shield, Gilbert recites from a parchment, spraying bits of half-chewed food in his bombastic style waving his mutton joint in time to his suspect meter and dubious rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: In Avalon, Lost Avalon, so the legends say, In mystery and mist, there valiant King Arthur lay. And resting with him, the brave, bold heroes of his day. Gilbert has risen and paces, carried off in the throes of overwrought rhyme. Bowen winces as the Priest starts his third stanza off with a piercing, dramatic, declamatory w  28

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Obhh, Avalon! Bright Avalon! The worried world's astray! Return forgotten glories that once held noble sway, And sweep the world's dank darkness away, away, away! : Gilbert glances at his audience in excited expectation!

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Your mutton is very good...Avalon is a fable, priest. ‘Ego ruffled, Gilbert rummages through his bag of scrolls

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: A fable? That's uneducated piffle, Bowen. JI can prove it. I have it right here. Somewhere here. (He can't find it) But I remember it. "Upon his death, King Arthur was taken to Avalon, a land of mist, to lie among his brother knights in a grove of stone upon a tor." Aha, here it is! He jerks out a scroll and unravels it, thrusting it out t Bowen. It's upside down. Gilbert twists it right side up.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: From the venerable history of Gildas the Scribe. Facts, my friend! Avalon is a holy place. And my pilgrimage a sacred duty. I will find it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: And when you do?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I'll pray to the souls of the sainted men buried there...Arthur and all the knights of Camelot.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: But, you know, Brother Gilbert, it's said not only Arthur lies at Avalon, but also the Gateway to the Underworld. So take care. The spirits you call may come. He tosses his mutton bone into the fire and works on his shield.  29

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I wish they would and bring back the days of chivalry and the Old Code.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: No prayers can resurrect that pale ghost... Gilbert has caught the regret in Bowen's voice.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Ride with me, my son. All knights need a quest. I think ours is the same.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Men of faith may follow a fable, priest. But my only faith is my sword...And I already have a quest.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: What quest?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: To slay all dragons...And one, in particular... Bowen's shield is finished, he holds up in the firelight inspect it. Gilbert's face lights up in awe and pleasure, though he's found the hero of his next epic poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen rides out of a dark forest into the light along the bank of a shallow creekbed. As his horse steps into the water, Bowen reins him up, leaning down in the saddle, examining... A DRAGON TRACK...impressed in the mud, visible through th clear, rippling water. Bowen glances up and smiles. A gentle WATERFALL spills ov an OVERHANG OF ROCK. His dragon will be there. Bowen jerk up his lance and reins his steed toward the falls.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT, (0S)
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo! GILBERT..."hallooing" for attention, stands atop a clump rocks on the opposite bank. Muttering an oath, Bowen rides over to Gilbert who plops literary bag on the rocks and rummages through it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: 30 (pulls out ink) How do you prefer I write this?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Far away. Gilbert doesn't get it, chuckles, and fumbles in his bag.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, please, don't concern yourself with my safety. No, I meant style. Verse. Meter. Shall I spice it up with a poetical flourish or just the cold hard facts? Gilbert's voice booms out above even the rushing falls. H ‘unrolls some blank manuscript. Bowen seethes exasperated

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Ssssh! We'll be the only things cold and hard around here if you don't shut up! Bowen pokes his lance through the scroll, jerking it away Gilbert indignantly snatches it back.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: That's a fine attitude. I come to immortalize you and you try to muzzle the mouth of chronicle, lop off the tongue of truth. It's all very well to go about hacking and whacking dragons, but if a dragon falls in the forest and no one hears about it, does it make a thud?! Exasperated, Bowen starts to ride off. Gilbert squats dow on a rock still, preparing to write, still railing at Bow

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: You're nothing without the likes of me. Heroics don't make heroes, ballad-makers do. The quill is mightier than the swo..! Suddenly, AN GIANT EYE opens up between Gilbert's legs, Gilbert lays his parchment on the "rock" and scrawls acro it with his quill. The eye blinks in agitation and sudden the "rock" starts to shift and move.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: +»-ord ...duh ...duh ...aah! Gilbert falls from the shifting "rocks", tumbling down toward... BOWEN...crashes onto him, then over the horse's back, splashing into the water. Bowen whirls back to the sound More splashing, just in time to see...  31 A DRAGON TAIL...slither along the creek, disappearing int the waterfall. The "rock" on which Gilbert was perched ha also disappeared. Bowen spurs his horse and charges for the falls. But he's stopped by... A BATTERED BREASTPLATE...flying out from the waterfall, splashing in the stream in front of Bowen who steadies hi nervous steed.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON, (0S)
dialogues.text: That's what's left of the last fellow who entered uninvited.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: That doesn't frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: No? How about this? Or this? or this? A barrage of crumpled armour and bones careens out. Half it crashes into Gilbert, trying to rise out of the stream The monk scampers out of the debris and has barely got to feet when suddenly the complete skeleton of a horse and r comes jangling through the falls, clattering in a heap. Their splash washes over Gilbert and sends him flopping b into the stream. Bowen's horse whinnies and rears.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: I could go on. I've quite a collection.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I won't be added to it. Bowen thrusts his lance at the figure on the other side o the fall. But the pike is yanked on from the other side o the waterscreen and Bowen, still gripping it, is yanked a with it. He spills from the saddle, somersaulting into th creek. A moment later, the two pieces of his broken lance shoot of the waterfall, the steel pointed end nearly impaling B as it jabs into the creekbed beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ON GILBERT
dialogues.text: Supine in the creek. Water spritzes from his mouth. He si up in time to see Bowen draw his sword and buckler and en into the cave through the waterfall. Gilbert sees his canvas sack floating by, he snatches it and, rummaging for another quill and parchment, starts to compose out loud.  32

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Into the mouth of death he strode Into the grimey gloom. Into a pit of fear unknown, Perhaps to court his doom, A FLASH OF FLAME backlights the waterfall, followed by a BLAST OF STEAM that rolls out from the falls, slamming Gilbert back into the creekbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOLT OF FLAME deflects against Bowen's shield, sparks h and smoke against the moist cavern floor. Bowen grins up the DRAGON -- A HULKING, HAZY SHADOW, in the smoky dark - lurking on a shelf of rock above him. The Dragon does hav quite a collection. Bones and armour litter the place.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Little damp for fire, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Why must you knight-errants out to make a name for yourselves always pick on us dragons?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I don't need a name...and I have a collection of my own. Bowen holds out his shield. The dragon horns glint ina rainbow of sunlight prismed through the waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Oh! One who kills for money, are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: It's honest enough work! Ridding the country of you lot. One must earn a living.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Yes...one must live. No way round then but to have at it, since you seek profit in this.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Don't flatter yourself. No profit this time, purely pleasure. Bowen draws his sword. The dragon's eyes widen in recognition!

dialogues.speaker: THE SWORD
dialogues.text: ---And the talon-scratched GROOVE in the blade.  33

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The dragon eyes Bowen warily.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Perhaps less pleasurable and more costly than you think. Bowen's mouth drops as the Dragon swoops off the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon swoops out of the waterfall in a GUSH OF WIND WATER. Spreading out his magnificent wings to their full extension, he sweeps up over a startled Gilbert. Patches -his hide glisten irridescently. An awesome, glorious creature.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Gilbert, craning back to gaze at the creature in dropped- jawed amazement, gets smaller and smaller as the dragon circles higher and higher in the sky. Gilbert, leaning ba a little too far, flops back into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOWEN...dashes out of the falls and onto his horse. Gilbe just rising, ducks for cover in the water again as the kn gallops past him into the woods after the dragon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen races through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon skims the treetops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen, at full gallop, places his reins in his teeth, and yanks a set of KNOTTED STRINGS from his saddle pommel. The flaps of his saddle-bags pop open. A BOLO-CHAIN catapults out, shoots skyward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chains BOLOS spread and widen as they spin up.  34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon looks back to see the Bolos ensnare one of his hind legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Bulldog fashion, Bowen wraps the chain around his sadd horn, continuing to keep pace with the Dragon above. Then the saddle harness snaps...and both saddle and Bowen still grasping the chain, are dragged across the ground a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon lunges through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clutching the chain for dear dear, still in the saddle, careening through the underbrush, sometimes dragging on t ground sometimes, whirling in the air, clanking stones an trees. Birds and small animals scurry from thickets. He avoids a near-collision with a tree as the Dragon suddenl veers his course, taking Bowen straight into the path of. ANOTHER TREE...with a dead log leaning against it. Both Bowen and the saddle ride up the log. Bowen leaps from th saddle running up the leaning log as he sees the chain th through the forked branches of a tree. Grabbing the saddl Bowen wedges it in the fork. It works. For a moment. Then the Dragon's momentum partially uproots the tree, causing Bowen to leap from th jostled dead log which comes careening down behind him. H tumbles and rolls and the tree just misses him. He peeks over over the trunk to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLUR OF DRAGON, at the end of its snared chain, plummet downward behind a clump of trees. There is a CRASH as the air fills with dust and dirt and broken tree limbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbert, on Merlin, rides in pursuit of the duel, composi as he goes, voice vibrating, ink slopping all over the pl

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: The sword against the fang and claw The flame against the shield. The man, the beast, which would win? Ahhhh! The scream is because his ink has spilt all over the manuscript, obliterating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen staggers up, dazed and dizzy, and starts to follow trail of chain. up over the ridge where the dragon crash- landed. No sooner has he disappeared than Gilbert arrives, mumbli to himself trying to re-capture his poem as he ties Merli up.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Blahblah Sword...fang and claw -..Flame against...shield... Blah, blah, blah, which would win? Unhh...shield, field, wield, peeled...Aha! Whose bones would flesh be peeled? Eww! Making a face at the line, he grabs more quills, manuscri and ink.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: No, no...Whose fate would soon be sealed! He likes the line. Smiling, he scurries over the ridge to find...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen, sword drawn, charging down into a small clearing w the Dragon, snarls and snaps, struggling to untangle the from his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Fleeing from an honourable challenge? What manner of Dragon, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: You won't live long enough to find out! The dragon's tail flanges out with sharp surrated edges a swipes at Bowen. Bowen blocks the blow with his blade, bu nearly loses his balance. Again, the tail strikes, smashi against his shield. Again, the tail flails out. Too close. Bowen ducks just i time as the tail slices a tree behind him in half.  36

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: You're good. Haven't had this sort of challenge in some time.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Nor likely to again. Bowen has rolled for cover behind a thick log. The dragon tail follows him, chopping huge chunks out of the log as though slicing celery. Bowen rolls to the end of the log, inches ahead of the carving tail which suddenly bites a little too deep and g wedged in the trunk of the log. The dragon shakes his tail, trying to get it loose, bounc -the log up and down. Realizing, the Dragon's tail is out comission, Bowen springs up, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Over-confident, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Hardly, but if you win, you'll be out of work. Bowen approaches cautiously as the Dragon manuevurs to confront his enemy.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Ha! I'11 keep on till I've exterminated every last one of you.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: I am the last one. Bowen stops dead in his tracks. And lets down his guard.. the Dragon snorts a FIREBALL from his nostril. Bowen leap back as the fire explodes against the tree.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: You're just trying to save your scaly hide with tricks. Bowen ducks as another fireball strikes behind him.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Haven't you noticed pickings rather slim of late? They have been. And Bowen realizes it. But as he cautious edges in toward the dragon, he brazenly taps the latest addition on his dragon-horn shield.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I got this one just the other day.  37

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: So you killed the Scarred One? He and I were the last. Must have been a proud kill, warrior. How much gold did his toothless, tattered carcass put in your purse?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours? The Dragon's taunts rankle Bowen, which is just what the Dragon wants. For he notices Bowen is stepping very near chain still attached to the Dragon's foot.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Couldn't have been much. And you'll kill me for sport. And when there are no more dragons to slay, how will you make your way, knight?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Shut up, you! Bowen raises his blade to strike, but as he does he strad the chain. The Dragon pulls back his foot, the chain snap up and catches Bowen mid-crotch. Bowen goes tumbling, los his shield. The Dragon rears up, opening his jaws. AND OPENING! They DISTEND like a snake's, stretching inordinately wide as s eyeteeth fangs suddenly spring out...

dialogues.speaker: ON GILBERT
dialogues.text: Who screeches and cover his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ON BOWEN
dialogues.text: Watching as the the black maw of the Dragon descends on h ALL BECOMES BLACKNESS, until...

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: «.-Uncovers his eyes, expecting the worst. It isn't...

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Bowen lies in the dragon's jaws, his sword tip tickling t Dragon's palette. And no one's moving.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: If your teeth come down, my sword goes up. Right into your brain!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: They're still not moving. Still in the same positions. Th dragon's unhinged jaws still stretched to their aching maximum. Bowen tries to discreetly sneak his blade up.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: (tongue-tied) Ifb your sworb cums ufp, ma teef cum down.

dialogues.speaker: ON GILBERT
dialogues.text: --.-wearily watching and writing...

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (scribbling) Till moonlit night, the titans duelled. In deadly combat bound... (yawns) Oh, who'd the fatal falter make, Whose blood «--would...stain......the ground... Gilbert's quill slides off the parchment as his head flop down on it and he falls asleep, his mouth agape in mid-ya

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen. crouches uncomfortably inside the mouth, propping sword arm up with his other hand, staring up at the fangs He notices a PIECE OF CLOTH stuck between the back teeth. Bowen gives it a tug. It's a sleeve...with a SKELETAL HAN still in it. Bowen recognizes the ring on the bony finger and drops it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Sir Eglamore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen throws the hand away in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Thanffs! Been stug ufp dere fa monffs! Cuud you ged your elba aff ma tongue.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Why should you be comfortable? My armour is rusting in your drool. And your breath is absolutely foul!

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Wad da you expekd wiff Sir Eglamaa rotting batwan ma molars?...Oh, my mouf ith dry...  39 Suddenly, the dragon starts to cough. Hacking rumbles rol up his throat. Bowen, rocking on the tongue, winces at th smell of the breath.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUGE BALL OF SALIVA rolls up the Dragon's throat and sm Bowen in the face. He wipes off, growling.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Watch it!

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Sorry! Seems we'rr in a bid ab a stalemade, wuudn't you thay?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (not giving an inch) But I can go three days without sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: I can go fhree weegs. This rattles Bowen's confidence, but he rebounds.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I'll stab you before I nod off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon, jaws aching, eyes rolling, is peeved.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Und I'll chompf you. Marbewous. We kull eagh ofper, doen neiffer aff us any guud.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: What do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: A troose! Ged out aff ma mouf and led's tag aboud it face-ta-face. More than happy to leave, Bowen starts to edge downward o the tongue, but before he pulls his sword away he has sec thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: How do I know I can trust you?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: I gib you ma word!  40

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: A dragon's word is worthless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon's tongue flaps up with an exasperated snarl, jostling the precarious perched Bowen.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Stubborn lout! The dragon suddenly arches his tongue up and Bowen slides his slippery perch...falling out of the Dragon's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: -EXT. WOODS
dialogues.text: Bowen plops from dragon's mouth onto the ground, his swor clattering nearby. He looks up as a scaly paw clamps down him, pinning him in place. The Dragon cranes his neck dow his eyes searing into Bowen.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I should have known. Go on! Kill me}

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: I don't want to kill you! Never did! (quietly;solemnly) And I don't want you to kill me... (savagely) How do we gain? If you win, you lose a trade. If I win, I wait around for the next swordslinger thirsting to carve a reputation out of my hide... (laments) I'm tired of lurking in holes and skulking in darkness! My life may be miserable, but I must not di...! He mysteriously stops, the thought unfinished.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Now if you insist, we can pursue this fracas to its final stupidity. or you can listen to my alternative. The Dragon releases Bowen. Perplexed but suspicious, he staggers to his feet, reeling for his sword. He's exhaust and the sword is too heavy to lift. He can barely turn ba to see if the dragon is coming in for a sneak attack. But there is no attack, The Dragon hasn't moved. He too i spent and sags to ground with a heaving sigh, gazing at B with disappointed eyes. Bowen drops to the ground too. He's tired...and curious.  41

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: What alternative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rosy rays of dawn filter through the forest foliage. Birds twitter. Crickets chirp. And someone snores. Gilbert. Still face down on his epic poem. A PINE CONE falls from above, thudding on his rump. Gilbe snorts, stirs, and rises, his face smeared with ink. He tries to decipher his equally blotched parchment. Then he remembers and, staggering to his feet, panics.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Bowen! He scans the area. Nothing. No signs of victory or deafea Or even that a battle had taken place. Gilbert spies something in a bush. He gingerly plucks it It's a SLEEVE. A BONY HAND slips from it. Yes... the late Sir Eglamour. But Gilbert jumps to the wrong conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. Poor chap. Picked clean. Gilbert crosses himself and, sadly looking at the ink- blotched manuscript in his hand, crumples it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVERAL PEASANTS manually turn a LARGE GRINDING WHEEL aro a flat mill stone under the supervision of Felton's BULLY BOYS, OTHER PEASANTS nearby thrash the wheat. STILL OTHER collect the milled flour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCAFFOLDING and ACTIVITY surround Felton's stone manor ho As MASONS measure and trim and CARPENTERS pound, A PRETTY LITTLE MINX with tousled hair langourously leans in the doorway, lacing up her undone doublet. A HAND reaches over her shoulder and slides a money pouch down into her ample cleavage. She smiles up to find... FELTON...smiling back, his own jerkin undone, holding up pants in one hand. With the other, he leads the girl back into the house. CAMERA PANS UP TO: THE WORKERS...on the scaffolding. It overlooks the wheatfield, where labourers are harvesting the wheat.  42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the peasants harvest the crop, A YOUNG BOY looms INTO FRAME, staring wide-eyed up at the sky and... EXT. FELTON'S MILL - SKY ABOVE FIELD — DAY ---the Dragon suddenly swoops down PAST CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy turntails and runs, frantically waving his arms a the others and yelling.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Dragon! Dragon! The workers looks up and then scatter to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon dive-bombs the wheat, loosing TWO STREAMS OF F through the now-empty field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peasants flee from the fire behind and the billowing black cloud of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon sweeps through the column of smoke, causing a vortex, winging his way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ++-the Mill. The workers, spying the dragon, abandon thei post. A BULLY-BOY grabs a whip and starts after them, but sudden wind blows chaff into his face. He swats it away i time to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dragon takes aim at the mill and...shoots TWO FIRE BA from his nostrils.  43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mill explodes. The Dragon swoops through the burning wreckage. The dazed bully-boy watches him go. He hears a CREAKING behind him and turns. The MILL WHEEL teeters unsteadily on the stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are cries and smoke and people dashing to and fro. Felton, jerkin undone, holding up his unbelted pants, rus out of the house, his dishevelled Minx behind him. He's aghast at the chaos, then hears a voice behind hin.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN, (0S)
dialogues.text: Pesky critters, dragons... Felton whirls to see Bowen, ahorse, armed to the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: ...like big rodents. You never seem to get rid of them... Felton loses a grip on his pants. They fall to his ankles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felton, still holding up his pants, dickers hotly with Bo

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Thievery! Gouging!

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: You owe me from last time and I want that in advance too! The Minx strokes Bowen's horse and smiles coyly at the knight. Bowen smiles back and winks.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: I won't pay it! He gestures emphatically with his arms. And his pants fal down again. As he leans over to pick them up, the MILL WH suddenly rolls past him. Felton jerks up. And his pants g down again as he, Bowen, the Minx, and the horse all turn their heads and watch the twirling juggernaut collides into... THE SCAFFOLDING...sending stone, wood, and workers flying Felton stares at his damaged house. Then at Bowen. Then a the Minx. He grabs the drawstring dangling from the Minx' cleavage and yanks out the MONEY PURSE he gave her earlie He flings it at Bowen with a disgruntled gesture...and, o more, his pants fall down.  44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEASANTS line the walls and yard of the manor house. Felt pants secure, sits in a chair in the front of the crowd, flanked by his Bulley-boys, with the Minx at his feet. Everyone is staring at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +..a harvested wheatfield at the edge of a LAKE. Bowen is manuevering an OX towing a CART OF BOULDERS. He brings th ox to a halt. The cart is ballast, attached via ropes and pulleys to a CATAPULT CONTRAPTION called "A WHACKER". Bowen goes to an adjustable TRIPOD and loads it with a heavy HARPOON. Calculating and adjusting, Bowen sights... THE DRAGON...who comes sweeping into view. BOWEN...slices the ROPE-TRIGGER with his sword and... EXT, FELTON'S MILL - LAKE - DRAGON'S POV — DAY .+.the HARPOON shoots from its cradle and zooms up toward target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon skillfully positions himself to take the harpo under his wing where his claw clamps shut on the shaft, catching it in mid-flight. But to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CROWD and FELTON...it looks like Bowen's scored a dir hit. An impression helped immeasurably by Dragon's spectacular, if overwrought, death scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dragon gasps a yelp, does mid-air pirouette, a twisti half-gainer, and then a death-throe spin captured in SLOW MOTION, before he does a final spiral tha sends him plummetting below the surface of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd breaks into raucous cheers as the dragon hits t surface. All but Felton who turns to his Thugs.  45

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Get my money back. They start down the hill,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen's foreseen this. He gives a shrill whistle. Bowen's horse, awaiting cue, emerges from behind a haystack and a gallops past, Bowen swings in the saddle and rides off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---toward the still~burning mill, laughing, jingling the Money pouch in a nose-thumbing taunt as he chokes the Thu on his dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the crystal surface of the lake, THE CAMERA PICKS U THE DRAGON...gracefully swimming along, leaving in its wa stream of bubbles from his nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Dragon stealthily creeps onto the bank from the la he hears a "BAAA!". A FLOCK OF SHEEP...graze by the bank. The Dragon's eyes gleam as his tongue flicks hungrily across his lips.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Hellooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowen rides across a grassy steppe, counting the day's ta Suddenly the dragon floats by him in the air, belly up, h wings flapping idly as he circles Bowen and tries to blow patch of wool from the corner of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Most profitable. I should have met you long ago, Dragon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: There is much gold in the world. When you have your fill of it and no longer need me...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: I am a Knight of the Old Code. My word is my bond.  46

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: No compunctions then?

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Well, such deception hardly befits a... (emphasizing) .--Knight of the Old Code... Dragon finally knocks the wool off his mouth with his paw Rankled, Bowen angrily snatches it out of the air, wheeli on the Dragon who's not longer there as he keeps idly circling Bowen. Bowen whips his head back to the Dragon n -on his other side.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: That's debatable! Fleecing Einon's lordly lackeys is a service to mankind.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Is it? When you squeeze the nobility, it's the peasants who feel the pinch. The Dragon's hit a sore spot and Bowen surily tries to deflect the blow.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Not my concern. Why stick my neck out for people afraid to risk their own? Don't clutter up a clever scheme with dubious morality. And stand still! I'm getting dizzy! The Dragon surreptitiously studies Bowen's vehement react with interest. He stops circling and lights.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: So be it... (emphasizing) Knight of the Old Code. The dragon strides along beside Bowen's horse.

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: (hotly) If I wanted my conscience pricked, I'd have stayed with the priest. And what does a dragon know of the Old Code, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: (quotes) "His blade defends the helpless. His might upholds the weak..."  47

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Stop it! I remember the words. And that's all it is! A memory. Dead and gone. And nothing...nothing... can bring it back. Bowen, voice thick with emotion, turns from the Dragon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: You sound like one who tried...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: And failed...So I no longer try to change the world, Dragon, but try merely to get by in it.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
dialogues.text: Yes, it's better than death, I suppose...

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: Is it? It comes out too bitter...Bowen self-consciously shifts t

dialogues.speaker: BOWEN
dialogues.text: .»--For you, I mean. I should think you'd welcome death. The last of your race. All your friends dead. Hated and hunted wherever you go...

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON
